org.gearvrf

Class GVRRenderData

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.GVRHybridObject
      • org.gearvrf.GVRComponent
        • org.gearvrf.GVRJavaComponent
          • org.gearvrf.GVRRenderData
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IRenderable, PrettyPrint

    public class GVRRenderData
extends GVRJavaComponent
implements IRenderable, PrettyPrint
    Encapsulates the data associated with rendering a mesh. This includes the mesh itself, the mesh's material, camera association, rendering order, and various other parameters.

      • setShaderTemplate

        public void setShaderTemplate(java.lang.Class<? extends GVRShaderTemplate> templateClass)
        Deprecated. does nothing currently, GVRShaderId now contains the shader template
        Set the shader template to use for rendering the mesh. A shader template generates the vertex and fragment shader based on the mesh attributes, textures bound to the material and light sources. The shader is generated by bindShader(GVRScene) bindShader } which is called automatically after initialization.
        Parameters:
        templateClass - subclass of GVRShaderTemplate describing the shader to use for rendering the mesh
        See Also:
        GVRShaderTemplate

      • bindShader

        public void bindShader(GVRScene scene,
                       boolean isMultiview)
        Selects a specific vertex and fragment shader to use for rendering. If a shader template has been specified, it is used to generate a vertex and fragment shader based on mesh attributes, bound textures and light sources. If the textures bound to the material are changed or a new light source is added, this function must be called again to select the appropriate shaders. This function may cause recompilation of shaders which is quite slow.
        Parameters:
        scene - scene being rendered
        See Also:
        GVRMaterialShader.getShaderType

      • bindShader

        public void bindShader(GVRScene scene)
        Selects a specific vertex and fragment shader to use for rendering. If a shader template has been specified, it is used to generate a vertex and fragment shader based on mesh attributes, bound textures and light sources. If the textures bound to the material are changed or a new light source is added, this function must be called again to select the appropriate shaders. This function may cause recompilation of shaders which is quite slow.
        Parameters:
        scene - scene being rendered
        See Also:
        GVRMaterialShader.getShaderType

      • enableLight

        public void enableLight()
        Enable lighting effect for the render_data. Note that it is different from GVRLight.enable(). GVRLight.enable turns on a light, while this method enables the lighting effect for the render_data.

      • disableLight

        public void disableLight()
        Disable lighting effect for the render_data. Note that it is different from GVRLight.disable(). GVRLight.disable turns off a light, while this method disables the lighting effect for the render_data.

      • enableLightMap

      • isLightEnabled

        public boolean isLightEnabled()
        Get the enable/disable status for the lighting effect. Note that it is different to enable/disable status of the light. The lighting effect is applied if and only if mLight is enabled (i.e. on) AND the lighting effect is enabled for the render_data.
        Specified by:
        isLightEnabled in interface IRenderable
        Returns:
        true if lighting effect is enabled, false if lighting effect is disabled.

      • setAlphaBlendFunc

        public void setAlphaBlendFunc(int sourceBlendFunc,
                              int destBlendFunc)
        Sets the blend functions for alpha blending between the screen (destination) and the texture (source) alpha. The blend functions are symbolic constants that specify how to scale the source and destination before they are added together:

        destAlpha = destBlendFunc * destAlpha + sourceBlendFunc * sourceAlpha

        The functions are defined the same way as in OpenGL. The source blend function defaults to GL_ONE, the destination blend function defaults to GL_ONE_MINUS_SRC_ALPHA.

        Parameters:
        sourceBlendFunc - blend function for source
        destBlendFunc - blend function for destination

        The supported functions are: GL_ZERO, GL_ONE, GL_SRC_ALPHA, GL_DEST_ALPHA, GL_ONE_MINUS_SRC_ALPHA, GL_ONE_MINUS_DEST_ALPHA, GL_SRC_ALPHA_SATURATE. Color blending or blending with a constant alpha are not supported.

        See Also:
        #getDestBlendFunc() #setAlphaBlend(boolean)

      • getSourceAlphaBlendFunc

        public int getSourceAlphaBlendFunc()
        Gets the source blend function for alpha blending. The blend functions are symbolic constants that specify how to scale the source and destination before they are added together:

        destAlpha = destBlendFunc * destAlpha + sourceBlendFunc * sourceAlpha

        The functions are defined the same way as in OpenGL. The source blend function defaults to GL_ONE.

        Returns:
        constant value for source blend function
        See Also:
        #getDestBlendFunc()

      • getDestAlphaBlendFunc

        public int getDestAlphaBlendFunc()
        Gets the destination blend function for alpha blending. The blend functions are symbolic constants that specify how to scale the source and destination before they are added together:

        destAlpha = destBlendFunc * destAlpha + sourceBlendFunc * sourceAlpha

        The functions are defined the same way as in OpenGL. The destination blend function defaults to GL_ONE_MINUS_SRC_ALPHA.

        Returns:
        constant value for source blend function
        See Also:
        #getSourceAlphaBlendFunc()

        Parameters:
        drawMode -

      • setTextureCapturer

        public void setTextureCapturer(GVRTextureCapturer capturer)
        Set the capturer for this texture. If capturer is null, the existing capturer is removed. Whether the capturer takes effect depends on the shader associated with GVRMaterial. In order to support the texture capturer, a native shader should check RenderData::get_texture_capturer. See ExternalRendererShader as an example.
        Parameters:
        capturer - The capturer.

      • getCastShadows

        public boolean getCastShadows()
        Checks if a renderable object can cast shadows.
        Returns:
        true if shadows are cast, false if not.
        See Also:
        setCastShadows(boolean), GVRLightBase.getCastShadow()

      • setCastShadows

        public GVRRenderData setCastShadows(boolean castShadows)
        Indicates whether a renderable object will cast shadows or not. By default, all objects cast shadows. Transparent objects cast non-transparent shadows. This function lets you disable shadow-casting.
        Parameters:
        castShadows - true to cast shadows, false to not cast shadows
